user: Explain the relationship between Value-at-Risk (VaR) and Conditional Value-at-Risk (CVaR). Under what market conditions would CVaR be significantly higher than VaR?
assistant: VaR is merely a threshold—a specific point on the loss distribution at a confidence level. It tells you 'we are X% sure we won't lose more than this'. CVaR (or Expected Shortfall) is the integral of the tail *beyond* that threshold. It's the average loss when things actually go wrong. CVaR becomes significantly higher than VaR when the return distribution exhibits high kurtosis—'fat tails'. In a crisis or 'black swan' event, VaR fails to capture the magnitude of the disaster, while CVaR exposes it. It's the difference between ignoring the cliff and measuring how far you'll fall.
